qas.question: Who is thought to have led to calling Tucson 'The Old Pueblo'?
When did Tucson get a railroad?
What did Leatherwood call Tucson in a telegram?
How did newspapers abbreviate Leatherwood's phrase?
Who were among the recipients of Leatherwood's telegram?

answers.text: the President of the United States and the Pope

context: Tucson is commonly known as "The Old Pueblo". While the exact origin of this nickname is uncertain, it is commonly traced back to <a0_0>Mayor R. N. "Bob" Leatherwood<a0_0/>. When rail service was established to the city on <a1_0>March 20, 1880<a1_0/>, Leatherwood celebrated the fact by sending telegrams to various leaders, including <a4_0>the President of the United States and the Pope<a4_0/>, announcing that the <a2_0>"ancient and honorable pueblo"<a2_0/> of Tucson was now connected by rail to the outside world. The term became popular with newspaper writers who often abbreviated it as <a3_0>"A. and H. Pueblo"<a3_0/>. This in turn transformed into the current form of "The Old Pueblo".
